title: About Plugins
synopsis: We explain federated wiki plugins. We define their role interpreting content, recount our experience writing many, describe principles and strategies for future plugins, and offer a step-by-step guide for new plugin authors. We'll also collect pointers here to good plugins when they emerge.

title: About this site
synopsis: This is my general federated wiki.

title: Add an External Link
synopsis: External Links are used to provide additional information, context, or citation to a wiki article. Here we talk about when to use external links, and how to add an [[External Link]] to a page.

title: Add an Image
synopsis: We've made an encyclopedic page at this point, and it's time to add some other items to it. Here we add an image.

title: All Pages in Neighborhood
synopsis: We've talked about the Neighborhood, but have not gone into it in great detail. Here we talk about what the Neighborhood is, and how to list all pages in it.

title: Assignments
synopsis: This is the methodology we'll be using for this Happening.

title: Backup
synopsis: You will want to make backups of the sites you own or host for others. Don't confuse the journal with a backup strategy. The journal tells others how the pages you decide to keep got the way they are. If you loose pages, the journals go with them.

title: Bookmark Key Pages
synopsis: This really isn't an optional step, although people tend to skip over anything that tells them to bookmark a page. I'm not sure why.

title: Browser Within a Browser
synopsis: Fedwiki (as it stands now) is a "newer kind of browser inside an older one" (Ward). It achieves this by using features of HTML 5.

title: Choose the Right Browser
synopsis: Federated Wiki uses fairly advanced HTML to accomplish what it does. In our experience, only Chrome and Firefox provide good experiences.

title: Conversations
synopsis: We've devised several mechanisms for recognizing and joining conversations within members of a community centered on a page title used as a topic.

title: Copy Pages
synopsis: You can copy pages from remote sites into your own with a click of one button. The page becomes yours with attribution as expected.

title: Create and Claim a Site
synopsis: Down at the bottom of your page (the [[Footer]]) there is a blue button (the [[Login]]). On systems running our Node code, it will say either "Sign In" "Sign Out" or "Claim with your Email".

title: Data
synopsis: We describe what data wiki stores, how it is kept, what you can change, and what happens when you do.

title: Data not Layout
synopsis: Pages are stored on federated wiki sites as JSON, a simple, easily parseable data format. You can see what this format looks like by clicking JSON at the bottom of the page.

title: Discoverable but not Obvious
synopsis: Identity and citation has to be discoverable -- that's part of the deal, the BY in the CC-BY-SA. But it does not follow that citation should be obvious. In fact, there are many reasons to to background citation.

title: Embed Video
synopsis: Embedding video is similar to adding an image. Instead of dragging and dropping an image onto [[Factory]], however, you are going to drag and drop a URL.

title: Execute a Cross-Page Move
synopsis: You can drag paragraphs up and down. Try it with these paragraphs. Click, hold, drag, then drop.

title: Federated Wiki on Digital Ocean
synopsis: At some point you may want to run your own Federated Wiki site, or perhaps set one up  for friends or a class. We've had good luck installing on Digital Ocean, which currently offers very cheap hosting and a much simpler setup than services such as Amazon Web Services.

title: Federation
synopsis: Federation gets title billing in the name. It is one of the key features, but not the only one.

title: Federation REST Services
synopsis: Members of the Federation provide simple CGI's on a server they own, programmed in whatever language they prefer, which responds at the URL specified with [[Fedwiki Page Json]].

title: Fedwiki Sites
synopsis: Follow  [[Changes to this Site]], or [[Changes to Fedwiki Sites]], to see what we are [[Currently Working On]]. Use [[Fedwiki Tools]] to author new content.

title: Fedwiki Tools
synopsis: Here we list a few tools that are of particular use in managing and creating [[Fedwiki]] content. Check [[Recycled pages]] to find deleted pages.

title: Field Guide to the Federation
synopsis: We show you what we find interesting in the federation and suggest how you can make yourself at home here.

title: Find Sites
synopsis: When you find a federated wiki site you can browse from there to even more sites. A page from a site becomes yours when you copy it (a fork) leaving a trail back to the source and its neighbors.

title: Find The Beginning
synopsis: The first page of any site is called Welcome Visitors. It is the page you see if you specify no other page in a site's URL. One click takes you to this page for any site.

title: Forking
synopsis: Forking is a technical term, derived from the sort of fork in the phrase "a fork in the road". It's "to split off".

title: History Travels With Page
synopsis: Because federated wiki pages travel between servers frequently, we can't rely on the server to maintain page histories. Therefore the history of each federated wiki page travels with each page.

title: Hosting
synopsis: A computer with a modern operating system and networking software can host the wiki server. This combination of resources can be found in many places.

title: How to Add Plugins
synopsis: The fed.wiki.org family of servers have been configured with a variety of plugins, many of which were experiments built to test the plugin concepts. User-oriented documentation is included in the server's how-to pages.

title: How To Wiki
synopsis: Here we describe how to use the web interface to the federated wiki. Read [[About Federated Wiki]] to learn about the project. If you are just starting to write in your first wiki then read the [[Field Guide to the Federation]].

title: Hypertext History
synopsis: Assignment is below. If you have not done an assignment yet, you should look see [[Assignments]].

title: Ideas of Federated Wiki
synopsis: Federated Wiki combines a few powerful, well-chosen ideas. It's helpful to know what these are. Most of these ideas exist someplace else, the particular power is the combination of the ideas in a single environment.

title: In a Nutshell
synopsis: Federated Wiki is less like Microsoft Word, and more like Excel.

title: Incremental Pages
synopsis: A wiki buds new pages as the need for them emerges. At this point in creation we challenge our future selves to thoughts beyond our immediate needs else the new remains only a footnote to the old.

title: Incremental Paragraphs
synopsis: A complete thought is more important than a complete sentence. Write to be read in progress. Expect your work to be consumed and discarded before it is finished.

title: Know Possible Traps
synopsis: Federated Wiki should be regarded as a Developer Release or Technology Preview. Expect certain things to go wrong. Roll with it....

title: Learn Shift-Click Magic
synopsis: Modifier keys are used heavily in Federated Wiki. Shift-click is one such modifier key. To use it, hold down your shift key while executing your normal click action.

title: Lineup
synopsis: The lineup is the list of wiki pages currently displayed within one tab, in order, with duplication possible.

title: LineUp Links
synopsis: Presently [[wiki links]] implement internal links within [[the federation]], using a mechanism we call [[collaborative links]]. Here I outline a proposal to extend this mechanism to enable wiki links to open a number of lineup pages.

title: Maintaining a Custom Wiki
synopsis: You will want to include your custom plugins in some or all of the servers you operate. Here we explore various workflows that simplify this task.

title: Make an Encyclopedic Page
synopsis: In this activity we will make a simple encyclopedic page.

title: Make an Index Page
synopsis: Index pages are used as entry points into your site's content. In pedagogical uses of federated wiki it can also function as a portfolio of student work. Here we show you how to make one.

title: Make Your Bio Page
synopsis: Your bio page helps users to understand who you are and why you might be running this site. This is how to make one.

title: Molecular Paragraphs
synopsis: In federated wiki the lowly paragraph (and in a broader sense the 'item') has a special place. Paragraphs have their own IDs and edit histories. They are draggable. They can define diferent formats (Markdown, HTML, Plain Text) and still live on the same page.

title: Neighborhood
synopsis: The neighborhood is the list of sites seen while browsing within one tab. The site's flags are shown in the footer.

title: Networking
synopsis: We describe how wiki hooks up to the network because it does so through mechanisms not so frequently used by end users browsing the web.

title: Parallel Pages
synopsis: We call this idea "Parallel Pages" but it's really a bigger idea than that. We just don't have a name for it.

title: Read History
synopsis: The gray squares at the bottom of a page is in an area called the [[Journal]]. Click a square to see other versions of the page.

title: Relocating
synopsis: We consider how one might move a whole site and why that might be necessary.

title: Rosters
synopsis: A roster is any list of sites assembled for the purpose of sharing. We describe common mechanisms for assembling and managing rosters.

title: Search Sites
synopsis: Search looks at the title and first paragraph of all pages in your [[Neighborhood]]. As you browse the federation more sites are added to your neighborhood so search can find more pages.

title: Security
synopsis: A site can be owned, or not. If it is owned we ask two simple questions "Who Are You?" and "Are You The Site Owner?". The separation of these two questions is important, as we will see.

title: Social
